@ChR1St0p4eR This is what many of the abolishment people would use as the narrative to claim abolishment is the answer. In this instance, the authorities may have prevented people from ending the events much sooner.  The counter being that authorities want to limit extraneous casualties and confusion from untrained people entering the insanity of the situation, which makes their jobs easier. While it is true that those parents being prevented from going in might have ended the situation, it is also possible that those same parents would end up as victims and tie up even more resources, or lead to police taking even longer to piece through the situation.

The problem, ultimately, is that we are examining the whole incident in hindsight. Are we sure that we would have done something different given the information they had at the time?

author: @michaeledward6623
text:
I am a police  officer in Canada, it is common practice, since Columbine that 'immediate rapid deployment' (IRD) in active killing situations means responding officers (non-tactical officers just Sworn Constables) make teams of 3 to 4 armed with Carbines and with ballistic vest respond by ignoring literally everything, including injured children, teachers and colleagues to eliminate the threat. In a barricaded hostage scenario without active killing, this changes drastically (usage of tactical teams). I just question, how does a person who's killed so many already, qualify as a barricaded hostage scenario? A lot of IRD training revolves around the idea that if someone is in a room  barricaded police entering  the 'funnel' (the door) will be shot, but a group with ballistic plates as a wall, should be able to overcome a shooter, even if multiple Officers are shot (the idea). 

I also don't understand how a State (Texas) with so many guns can make a 'school' a gun free zone, isn't this a straight up oxy moron? Canadian schools in the Toronto area, Surrey / BC lower mainland with gang gun problems have metal detectors and multiple police. Just seems a little bit well, stupid.

author: @samuelwallace2782
text:
The BORTAC team, from what I've heard was off duty. They showed up with what they had on hand and took the situation out of the hands of the police. 

The reason for the breach protocol is to put pressure on the shooter. Hostage rescue is incredibly tense, and every effort is made to keep the hostage taker calm, and if entry must be made, it is made by a team that trains specifically in hostage rescue. 
This wasn't a hostage situation, in was an active shooter. The officers or officer must attack, regardless of gear or backup, period. The purpose is to put pressure on the shooter as quickly and strongly as possible, because they usually end up taking their own lives.

author: @digitaltf
text:
Regarding law enforcement asking for keys to enter the classroom....

I was last involved with public schools over 25 years ago, but even then, the doorframes were heavy steel, the lock mechanisms were commercial grade and the doors themselves were heavy steel or 2-3" thick solid wood composite. The "battering ram"s used for residential entry would be to that kind of door is the equivalent of using a firecracker to a blow out a tree stump. It ain't gonna do squat to break down the door, even presuming the classroom door opens _inwards_ , in modern classrooms the doors are designed to open _outwards_ for emergency egress purposes and to _prevent_ easy breakins.

replies.author: @lindabelcher8087
replies.text: 🌠WiNdOwS🌠

replies.author: @digitaltf
replies.text:
@lindabelcher8087 if you're referring to exterior windows, most schools built after the 1970s that have opening windows the aperture is too small for an adult to get through.

If you're talking the windows in classroom doors, they're usually made of shatter resistant glass and often wire reinforced.... So breaking the window isn't a practical option for anything other than a distraction, and in a hostage situation would quite likely result in unfriendly gunfire towards whomever's at the door - which is generally something to be avoided. Even 3" of wood will not stop most rifle rounds.

author: @davejones9469
text:
*First off, Matt Christiensen had an interesting point about the convenient timing of everything as well. The shooter shot his grandmother, then started sending messages and even started his live stream before he drove over. The teacher that propped the door open (that he used to enter) did so about 20 mins before his arrival at the school. On top of that, he was shooting at people before he even got near the school, and the school was on lockdown I believe because police had already been called. Yet, the teacher who knowingly left a door open made no effort to get it closed, even when there was an obvious threat. Maybe it's a foil hat thing, but he explains the timeline much better and I'm as suspicious as him, which is mild to critical depending on how much you trust what we've been told.

Also, HOLY SHIT DUDE, I didn't know you had an incident with cops as a kid, I did too but I was even younger, maybe 8-10 at most. 
Me and a friend were playing in the park at our school, and we saw the police investigating the catholic school right next door. Naturally, we went over to see what was happening, and a cop came up and started asking us if we knew anything, and somehow I said something that made them actually cuff me and take me to the station, without my parents around or anything. I was fully interrogated and gave false testimony because I was scared as fuck, and I happened to guess which bathrooms were vandalized in the school (2 main level, one upstairs, just made sense to me). When my mom finally got there, I could hear her screaming at them the moment she was in the building, and she whisked me out of there while cussing the fuck out of those piece of shit cops.
She should've sued, but it's not as simple in Canada, unfortunately.

author: @samstevens7172
text:
I could be mistaken, but it appears the spokesman is with Tx DPS, or the state troopers.  That would not be the head of the local PD.  
it also has been reported that the belief was the shooter was barricaded and not with students, which would make it a bit more reasonable to not enter. 
As for weapons and equipment, it appears all or many of the officers shown had long guns and vests, which is all that you need to do a reasonable immediate response.  
Active shooter threat response has been taught and practiced for years; in response to Columbine, where SOP of establishing a perimeter and wait for the tactical team was shown to be the wrong way to handle school shootings.  
The only reasonable thing that makes sense was the police believed the story of the barricaded shooter, otherwise simple CYA would have required immediate response.  This does conflict with the recurrent 911 calls coming from the school, so something is screwy there.  
The only thing the BORTAC unit appeared to have was a ballistic shield, and maybe threat level III vests (for rifle protection) as such vests generally are not suitable for daily wear (although they exist).   
One of the BORTAC guys wasn’t wearing a helmet as he was wounded in the head, so that wasn’t a deterrent from deploying.  
I can only say by the what looks like a horrible performance by the officers on scene was they believed the barricade shooter story.   
Also, the “Scene commander” could have been just the highest ranking officer there.  Not necessarily anyone with command or tactical expertise.   
Just a horrible f*d up situation all around.

text:
I'm not sure how it is in Texas, but even in here in California, standard procedure for a shooter is terminate the threat immediately. After Columbine, officers are no longer required or allowed to wait for SWAT or other enforcement, instead immediately take measures to terminate or at least suppress the shooter.
I also don't buy the no firepower excuse, cuz even here in stupid and strict gun law California where even a semi auto .22 is considered an assault weapon, police are required at least a Shotgun and full auto, 30 round, 5.56 AR-15 and tac ballistic vest in each squad car. If the we hate guns state has those standard and required for our officers, no way Texas dosen't allow anything above a service pistol.
My state is a hellhole filled with morons, with some of the stupidest procedures that protect the criminals over citizens, so when officers from here have better procedure than Texas and claim to be underarmed......It dosen't seem right in the slightest.

Edit: No, it was not the border patrol tac team that killed and engaged the shooter, it was an off duty border patrol officer, the tac team entered AFTER the off duty officer neutralized the threat and had the hero off duty officer had been shot. The feds had appeared to the scene, but were acting as the local police were, arresting the parents who were trying to save the children.

text:
You can't rely on the government or any of their branches, such the police - not in a severe crisis. Corruption, politics, misconduct, and mismanagement aside, It's a simple question of availability and distribution. If resources (be they people, services, or materials) aren't available or can't be dispatched or distributed to you, at least in not time - then their existence is basically irrelevant to you in a crisis, even if they're of high quality.

Anyone who's ever had a break-in can likely attest to this. No matter how close the nearest police are, they likely won't arrive in time to drive off the invaders, let alone catch them. That is unless you get extremely lucky. By the time they arrive, the damage will have already been done, and the attackers will escape leaving no leads, case closed.

Now compound that fact with the fact that the police may be on standby at the site of the emergency, yet simply lack the ability or even merely the will to intervene. Even on a good day, you *cannot* simply rely on them. Other systems and protocols need to be in place, and despite never even wanting to be in the presence of a firearm if I don't have to, I've yet to be convinced that prohibiting them will stop the killings. Especially not if the police will just stand around doing nothing but restraining people who would actually put themselves in harm's way to assist.

author: @harpake
text:
I would not expect firings if what the police did happened here. I would expect criminal sentences for the officers. The law here says everyone has a duty to rescue and this includes the duty to assist the police in saving lives. The police has a duty to maintain security and to prevent crime and by neglecting their duties they would clearly be in violation of their duty to rescue. The police only have the right to abandon the measure if its completion could lead to an unreasonable outcome in relation to the objective pursued which clearly could not be reasoned with in this instance.

If there will be no criminal charges (provided no new evidence comes forward to somehow make their actions reasonable), then there need to be changes in your laws as this is not a reasonable way to run a society.
